issue.title: Option to autostart Tailscale after Android system restart
issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

I would like to be able to connect to/from my Android device after system restart without any extra steps. My super non-critical use case: I am running rtsp server on an older Android phone that I would like to be able to access with the steps to be taken after a restart. 

**Describe the solution you'd like**

I would like to have an "Auto-start after system reboot" option in the Android Tailscale app.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

Alternative is to simply just use a separate startup manager app, although less convenient.

**Additional context**

Nope.

comment.body:
Not implemented on android tv box...
checked the "Always-on VPN",not run after reboot,and not actived if open app

issue.title: FR: Way to automate tailscale SSH into a linux(debian 10 OS) device and add it to a useraccount
issue.body:
### What are you trying to do?

We are using Rock3c device to collect live data points in client sites and to remotely access these IoT devices. We are using tailscale SSH to login into these devices. 
Is there a way to automate the tailscale installation and adding it to a useraccount.
We tried to install tailscale assign it to a user account and flash the img across different devices, but we had a IP clash and duplicate device issue. So had to uninstall tailscale and delete everything from /var/lib/tailscale/tailscaled.state and reinstall and add sudo tailscale up --ssh got a new link for each device and then opening the link in a new browser adding it to the required email id. 
Is it possible to automate the whole process using a single script?


### How should we solve this?

_No response_

### What is the impact of not solving this?

It gets tough when the number of devices increase. If I have 1000-2000 Rock3c IoT devices or as the scale increases it takes a lot of time to add each and every device to the user.

### Anything else?

Is it okay if we disable the expiry key for all the devices because I feel renewing it for 1000 devices before due date approaches is close to impossible? Adding this to the automation script will also be useful because doing the disable expiry key for all devices is time consuming.

issue.title: iOS & macOS : device backup+restore accidentally clones tailscale keys
issue.body: A user reported that upon getting a new iPhone, they backed up their old iPhone and then restored the contents using Apple's tools, and this also copied the tailscale keys (visible because both devices now show the same Tailscale IP address). It was not obvious how to work around the problem. I think someone reported this with macOS previously, but I can't find the bug now. We should perhaps add some kind of "device identity" detection so that we regenerate keys when this happens. [Front conversations](https://app.frontapp.com/open/top_2ijtd)

comment.body:
Just experienced this issue when restoring a new iPhone from local backup on Mac. FYI, although not sure if this is relevant, I used an encrypted backup.

- Reinstall the app from both devices and reauthorize: did not work 
- Remove device from admin console and reauthorize: did not work
- Reset keychain from the settings on the old device and reauthorize: worked!

issue.title: Serve CLI should continue to work when control is unavailable
issue.body:
Serve CLI appears to be reaching out to control to get fetch the https feature status.

```
enabling https feature: error Post “http://local-tailscaled.sock/localapi/v0/query-feature?feature=serve”: context canceled
```

We should avoid this if possible.

commits.message:
net/dns/resolver: add subdomain resolver support in MagicDNS

This PR adds processing of subdomains that if there is an entry for a
wildcard entry in hosts for a domain, MagicDNS will resolve with the
host IP.

Fixes #15037

Signed-off-by: Richard Castro <richard@tailscale.com>

cmd/tailscale/cli: use status before doing interactive feature query

We were inconsistent whether we checked if the feature was already
enabled which we could do cheaply using the locally available status.
We would do the checks fine if we were turning on funnel, but not serve.

This moves the cap checks down into enableFeatureInteractive so that
are always run.

Updates #9984

Co-authored-by: Tyler Smalley <tyler@tailscale.com>
Signed-off-by: Maisem Ali <maisem@tailscale.com>

pull_request.title: cmd/tailscale/cli: use status before doing interactive feature query
pull_request.body:
We were inconsistent whether we checked if the feature was already enabled which we could do cheaply using the locally available status. We would do the checks fine if we were turning on funnel, but not serve.

This moves the cap checks down into enableFeatureInteractive so that are always run.

Updates #9984

net/dns/resolver: add subdomain resolver support in MagicDNS

This PR adds processing of subdomains that if there is an entry for a
wildcard entry in hosts for a domain, MagicDNS will resolve with the
host IP.

Fixes #15037

Signed-off-by: Richard Castro <richard@tailscale.com>

issue.title: Slow throughput over tsnet compared to Windows tailscaled
issue.body:
### What is the issue?

I have a go http server that serves up https://github.com/librespeed/speedtest.

I made this server accessible on my tailnet, using both system tailscale (windows 1.50) and embedded tsnet.

On a remote node across the country where I am accessing the speedtest, I confirmed via `tailscale status` there's a direct connection to both IPs.

When I invoke the browser based speed test, the speeds shown on the system tailscale IP will stabilize after a few seconds and in my case measure 35mbps. Hitting the same server on the same node using its tsnet IP, the speeds never stabilize, keep dropping, and are near 4mbps at the end of the test.

cc @eric

### Steps to reproduce

full standalone repro to come

here are the gin-gonic routes being used to drive the speed test:

```go
	r.GET("/garbage", func(c *gin.Context) {
		c.Header("Content-Description", "File Transfer")
		c.Header("Content-Type", "application/octet-stream")
		c.Header("Content-Disposition", "attachment; filename=random.dat")
		c.Header("Content-Transfer-Encoding", "binary")
		ckSize, _ := strconv.ParseInt(c.Query("ckSize"), 10, 64)
		if ckSize == 0 || ckSize > 2048 {
			ckSize = 4
		}
		data := make([]byte, 1024*1024)
		io.ReadAtLeast(rand.Reader, data, len(data))
		for ckSize > 0 {
			_, err := c.Writer.Write(data)
			if err != nil {
				break
			}
			ckSize--
		}
	})

	r.GET("/empty", func(c *gin.Context) {
		c.Status(200)
	})
```

### Are there any recent changes that introduced the issue?

Not sure, but I upgraded tsnet from 1.48 to `main` (which includes a gvisor bump) and did not observe any improvement.

I also ran the same test against a linux and macos server and observed the same behavior where the speed declines continuously over tsnet

### OS

Windows

### OS version

Windows 11

### Tailscale version

1.51.0-dev20231007

### Other software

_No response_

### Bug report

_No response_

comment.body: We are not seeing those `magicsock: ` error messages that would make it seem like the issue is that we are failing to set the buffer size. Does anyone have any other ideas on how to resolve this? It's greatly impacting our Windows users.

pull_request.title: ipn: introduce app connector advertisement preference
pull_request.body:
The preference will be later set by an up / set flag, and enables the node to offer app connector behaviors.

Updates tailscale/corp#15437

```
wget https://tailscale.com/install.sh
sh install.sh
```
